justification: “We adapted 26 items derived from the Positive Driver Behavior Questionnaire (P-DBQ) … We assessed eight positive driving behaviors…,” which were used as indicators of a prosocial driving style.

The authors note that aggression and violations from the P-DBQ were combined: “We assessed… five aggressive behaviors … and five violations… we computed a composite score for competitive driving style,” tying the competitive style to the same questionnaire.

“Driving styles have been well-documented … and the Driver Behavior Questionnaire (DBQ) … has been used to differentiate prosocial or aberrant driving styles,” explicitly linking the construct of driving style to the DBQ measure.
Under Measures: “Values. We used 57 statements from the Schwartz Values Instrument (Schwartz, 1992) to assess value priorities,” directly pairing the construct (value priorities) with the instrument.

In Appendix A the paper lists the specific benevolence items (e.g., Loyalty, Helpfulness) and notes they came from the Schwartz Values Instrument, showing this basic value is operationalised with that scale.
The same appendix states: “Power statements were Social Power, Being a Leader…,” identifying how the Schwartz Values Instrument measures the power value construct.
Appendix A: “Security statements were Personal and Family Safety, Social Order…,” indicating the security value is assessed with items from the Schwartz Values Instrument.
Appendix A lists “Stimulation statements were Creativity, Originality, Curiosity…,” showing the stimulation value construct is captured through the Schwartz Values Instrument.
